so yeah without getting too philosophical here uh we can say that us as humans we need intelligence in some form to be able to distill meaning from the phenomena around us but to be able to make more intelligent decisions by computing more data faster and with better outcomes has actually become one of the major goals and the holy grounds of machine learning and ai in the past decades
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, in search for different ways of intelligent computing, one way for us to categorize all of our recent efforts could be to talk about these categories, like machine learning and AI, quantum computing or neuromorphic chips.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Obviously, there are other ways of looking at these and other tools that we've developed, and they are all the right tools for the right purposes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They could all also have their own pros and cons, and what motivated us to look for new alternative ways of computing was that, for example, in machine learning and AI, we are facing challenges such as their high computational power, high power use, their catastrophic forgetfulness, or the fact that they require very large samples and very
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: long training times and they were also very susceptible to errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Or if you're talking about quantum computing,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Again, we have extremely high power usage.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: These are very isolated from the external world and very prone to errors, and they are not very adaptable.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And also, if you're looking at neuromorphic computing and the whole field around it, there's also limited error correction capabilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: variability between circuits and also they still require some sort of programming to some capacity to be able to do what we are designing them to do.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So basically in search for this alternative intelligent computing system that could actually solve some of these challenges that we have in these other categories, we thought that why not use the brain and the brain cells themselves
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: which are the most advanced intelligent systems that we know of.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And there's actually no need to prove that these brain cells are capable of doing very high order of computation.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So I'm not going to go into too many details of our setup because I think many of you might have heard or read about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But just to recap, firstly, what we do in cortical labs
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: to basically design and develop our system is that we use human iPSC cells, which are then differentiated to a neuronal phenotype.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: For the studies that we're going to talk to you about today, we also had primary cortical neuronal cell cultures from mice.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and all of these cell cultures were then plated onto max one high density multi-electrode arrays which basically enables us to stimulate the neurons and also record from them at the same time from the same cultures and well we saw and we showed that these cultures could actually survive for even
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: more than six months on these multi-electrode arrays.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: With our new products, new systems in this brand, we can go even way beyond six months and keep them healthy, keep them alive, keep them active, which gives us the capability of studying them for longer terms.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And for example, here is just a sample microscopy imaging, but you can see the dense interconnected population of these neurons that have been cultured and are active on the multi-electrode array.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So then we designed what we called initially Dishbrain, which is this closed-loop real-time system to interact with these neuronal cultures and embed them in the environments of the arcade game of Pong, which you can see here on the right-hand side.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is a famous arcade game.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You have one paddle and basically the paddle is playing against the wall, trying to hit the ball accurately.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And the first published work that we explained the system and we showed, you know, basically all our findings of the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I think you've seen it and you've talked about it before, but it basically explores the system in extensive detail, which I will not bore you with here with all of those details, but because it's important to know what's this closed-loop system that we're dealing with, I'm just gonna briefly talk you through,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: how it works and how it's designed.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Basically on each culture, which is integrated onto a multi-electrode array, we first predefined separate regions, one sensory region on top and two model regions on the bottom of this cartoon image that you can see on the left-hand side and the right-hand side.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: First, using the sensory region, we feed information about these hypothetical balls, x and y-axis locations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So imagine that game environment, you have the ball moving, you want to know where it is in that frame.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: so the x-axis location is actually uh encoded by rate coding between 4 and 40 hertz depending on how close the ball is to the paddle on the x-axis and also we use place coding where where we encode where the ball is on the y-axis
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: by only simulating one of the eight available sensory electrodes within the sensory region.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And these eight electrodes are actually evenly distributed along the y-axis.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So whichever part or segment the ball falls into, that sensory electrode is activated.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then we record from these two, again, predefined motor regions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: and compare their activities of all the channels in those regions, which are some of them are representative of the up movement, as you can see the arrows on this figure, and some of them are responsible for downward movement of the paddle.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then obviously comparing the activities of these two sub regions, we decide where the culture is moving the paddle in what direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then we need to close the loop by applying feedback to the same sensory region as we defined.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Again, this is another schematic, maybe to make things a bit more clear, but basically to explain our feedback loop, what happens is that if the ball is missed by the paddle, random unpredictable signal is applied for like four seconds at random sites in the sensory region.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then if the ball is hit accurately, a predictable repeated stimulation for a shorter amount of time is applied to all of the sensory electrodes.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So we then again record from these cells on top of these silicon chips, both during their rest state spontaneous activity for comparison reasons and during their embodiment in their gameplay environment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I'm just going to briefly
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: touch upon something you might all have been thinking of now that I have explained our feedback loop here that after designing the system and finding actual evidence that this particular type of feedback loop is actually enabling the neurons to be learning the game or to be performing the game better as we go on in time.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You could think of this clearly as some evidence supporting
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: the free energy principle that we've been talking about for a long time now, the fact that these neurons don't like surprise, don't like the unpredictable sensory feedback that they receive when they miss the ball is what seems to be driving them towards playing the game better and towards performing better in the game.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So this was really cool evidence that we found that could be actually explained by FPP as we all know about.

text: We could definitely talk more in detail about this, but I'm just going to go to our basically newest findings.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is a very, very short summary,

text: the percentage of aces or ace here is actually a bad thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, in our obviously never-ending search for the underlying mechanisms that could drive this behavior,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: In one of our more recent projects, we first wanted to compare the gameplay and rest sessions in terms of their connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: plasticity we assume that is happening during gameplay.

text: Hi, everyone, again.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Now to do this task that we've mentioned, first the challenge was that for every recording and for each channel we have a very very large time series of spiking activity.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So to make these sparse spiking patterns more interactable and easier to work with, first we decided to use a dimensionality reduction algorithm to
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: bring each channel time series to a lower dimensional space.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We use and compared different algorithms, including TISNI and isomap that you see here.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And as we can observe, interestingly, even in a very low dimensional space, such as a 2D space here, the first and second half of the
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: of each recordings were easily distinguished during gameplay, but not clearly in the rest.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: These figures are four sample cultures, and the two colors represent all the channels in each half of the recording.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we were motivated to continue this study in this lower dimension for higher interpretability and lower computational power use.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But then also having 1024 recorded channels still meant high computational complexity in our problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we have this hypothesis that most probably a lot of these channels are highly correlated and we might be facing redundancy of information when looking at all the available channels in the recording.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So for that reason, we designed this pipeline to eventually study the functional connectivity of channels and compare between gameplay and rest.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Very briefly, we first used T-SNE algorithm to map all channels' recordings to the lower dimensions, which is selected to be three here.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And then to select a smaller set of channels, which are good representatives among all the recordings, we stacked up the low dimensional representations of all gameplay sessions and using attacker decomposition, followed by K-Metroid clustering algorithm,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We chose the centroids of the channel clusters in this low dimensional space as the mutual representative channels.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We tried different numbers of clusters and got the best results by choosing 30 clusters and higher numbers of clusters show no significant improvement in the results.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Finally, we built functional connectivity networks using these 30 channels as nodes and the Pearson correlation of their spiking activities as the weight of the edges between each pair of channels.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But we were also interested in tracking the connectivity dynamics and changes in time
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: as learning occurred in the culture.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So what we looked at here was the changes in correlation between pairs of notes from the first two minutes to the last two minutes of the recordings.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And what we see here on the left,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And right are the average networks from all of our recordings, which is around 300 gameplay sessions and about 150 rest sessions.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: First of all, the extracted representative channels, which come from the sensor regions, are in green circles, and the ones from motor regions are in blue squares.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Now, the color of the edges indicates an increasing or decreasing correlation between nodes in red and black, respectively, and the edge thicknesses are related to the magnitude of these differences.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Simply by visualizing the data,
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: we saw significant differences between rest and gameplay where we observe many more positive edges or increase in correlation between channels.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And finally, to give you some more statistics of what we found happens as the network of channels evolves in time.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Here we can see the same five measures of network dynamics compared between the first and last two minutes in pink and green and also gameplay on top versus
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: rest session.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The gameplays are in pink and the rest are in green.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: First, we have the average weight of the functional connectivity networks, which shows a significant increase during gameplay, but not at rest.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Next, the modularity index that decreases significantly, but only at gameplay.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: That basically means that
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: the different clusters or modules of the network become more interconnected during the gameplay as time goes on.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The clustering coefficient also shows a significant increase only in gameplay, meaning that the neighbors of a given node have become more strongly connected between themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And finally, characteristic path lengths or the average shortest path between any pair of nodes in the network decreases significantly after 18 minutes or gameplay recording.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Now that we have found even more evidence of the dynamics of these networks, which could potentially give rise to the emergent learning that is observed in their behavior, in
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Then in another study, a Nexus study, we were also interested to do a direct comparison between the deep reinforcement learning algorithms and our normal cultures in the same game environment of Pong, but clearly only during the gameplay sessions.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We all know that RL algorithms that use deep neural networks in their structures have been developed to beat human experts in various games such as Atari games and have proven to be very strong players of these games given they have enough training.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But these algorithms suffer from different issues, such as modeling the rebar structure, sample inefficiency, reproducibility, as well as requiring high levels of computing power.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And these issues suggest that deep RL algorithms might actually differ fundamentally from human learning mechanisms and not be efficient to be a plausible model for human learning.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: That's why we were motivated and interested to do this research and comparison.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: In our work, we use three deep RL algorithms, DQN, A2C, and PPO, which are established to have good performance in Atari games and are robust tools in reinforcement tasks, particularly in games where the input is an image.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: But apart from the
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: traditional gray scale image input of the game environment, we also take a step further aiming to account for potential adversaries resulting from the increased dimensionality of the image input to the deep RL algorithms or so-called Kerasov dimensionality in machine learning terminology.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We designed two additional types of input information.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: first paddle and ball position design where we obtain a four-dimensional vector encoding the x and y coordinates of the ball and also the y coordinates of the paddles top and bottom
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And also the ball position design where we divide the y-axis of the gameplay environment to eight equal segments, each mimicking one of the sensory electrodes in the biological cultures that place code the information about the ball's y-axis.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Then the ball's x-axis position is used as the second element of this input vector, similar to the rate-coded component of the stimulation applied to the biological cultures that we had.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: This design is the most similar one to the cultures with the lowest dimension of the input vectors.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Also, we found that using the same number of training game episodes for biological neural networks and deep reinforcement learning algorithms in the image input design, the average Raleigh lens is highest for the human and mice cell cultures here in orange and blue, while they also achieve the lowest percentage of ACEs
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: and highest percentage of lung rallies.

speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: which is the same number used to train the biological cultures, but not sufficient for any of the algorithms.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: So we could eventually conclude that the RL algorithms showed the lowest sample efficiency, having the lowest improvement in learning given the same number of training episodes provided for all the groups.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And this was even despite the fact that these methods receive a higher information density compared to cultures.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Finally, we also explored a biologically inspired algorithm implementing an active inference agent that uses counterfactual learning.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: um improved learning rates observed in this biologically inspired learning protocol supports the potential of active inference agents to provide valuable insights into optimized learning strategies so and they can enhance our understanding of these dynamics however these active inference algorithms are um
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: still highly dependent on the chosen hyperparameters and require relatively higher power consumption compared to biological systems.
